Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Socially Relevant Computing in Pervasive Computing, Computer Vision, and Human-Computer Interaction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Socially Relevant Computing REU Site at UNC Charlotte engages a diverse group of undergraduate students in an intensive 9-week summer research experience. REU students conduct research as part of a collaborative research community, working with faculty, graduate students, and peers. Each project has a socially relevant theme, providing undergraduate students with the opportunity to apply and extend their computing knowledge and deepen their understanding of the societal and global impact of computing research. The goals of the program are to increase interest in attending graduate school, enhance preparation for careers in research and innovation, and broaden participation of underrepresented groups in the field of computing.

The REU students will be involved in research that leads to the creation of new technologies that support humans in socially relevant tasks, requiring advances in the areas of pervasive computing, computer vision, and human computer interaction. Projects include: creating robust and scalable methods to analyze large sets of medical images to support clinical decision-making and diagnosis, developing new algorithms and systems that support large scale scientific data collection in crowdsensing and citizen science projects, and creating novel interfaces and systems for analyzing user interactions while preserving privacy in intelligent spaces. More information about the Socially Relevant Computing REU Site can be found at the program website: www.reu.uncc.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals of the Socially Relevant Computing REU Site at UNC Charlotte were to: 1) develop students? research skills and confidence through problem-based learning and research training, 2) situate student learning in an authentic community of practice, including faculty, graduate students, and peers, and 3) broaden participation through socially relevant research in cutting-edge innovative, interactive applications. Students were recruited from throughout the US, and paired with faculty and graduate student mentors within one of four participating research labs to conduct research over the course of a 9 week summer program. Students completed projects in Visualization, Human Computer Interaction, Vision and Image Analysis, and Sensing and Networking to extend their computing knowledge to address problems that have a real-world impact.

This award has supported 30 undergraduate students in conducting research through the summers of 2014-2018. The site emphasizes participation of promising students from underrepresented groups in computing and from institutions that have limited research programs. Student belief in their computing skills (computing self-efficacy) and in research skills increased significantly after participating in our program. These findings indicate that the experience heightened the students? sense of competency, and increased their research skills. Students became highly engaged in their research projects, and considered the summer experience as exploratory for graduate pursuits. Students indicated that they developed persistence, coping and an affinity for a research identity.
